title: Measures of Central Tendency
text:
The goal of this post is to give a quick introduction to measures of central tendency - which is a fancy way of saying, how can we use a single number to summarize the contents of a data set. The three quantities we are concerned with will be the mean (average), median, and mode.
These are widely taught in pretty much every stats class, so here we will focus on conceptual meaning and interpretation.
Lets start with a simple data set for illustrative purposes with only five numbers: \((1, 4, 5, 10, 10)\)

title: Measures of Central Tendency
text:
References

Mercadante AA, Tenny S. Mode. [Updated 2023 Jul 17]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-.Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK540990

title: Rolling Averages
text:
Some Basics
An average is a common concept, it is a number which represents each data point within a range of numbers, giving equal weight to each number. While averages are fairly straightforward, the concept of rolling averages may not be as simple.
A rolling average is the average of a range of values within a given time frame which keeps moving forward to keep up incoming data as time goes on. Rolling averages help us include incoming data to adjust our average value and they can constrain the data we look at if we want to emphasize a certain set of values within a range.
Take budgeting for example. An average monthly spend ever since you opened your bank account would not be the greatest figure to help you work on your finances. It would not update with new data (e.g., transactions, withdrawals, deposits) and it includes all data within the range (is it really that useful to know how much you spent in a month when you were 15?) With a rolling average, you can constrain the time you look at (e.g., the last 3 months)
test test test

title: Measures of Dispersion
text:
The goal of this post is to give a quick introduction to measures of dispersion - which is a fancy way of saying, how can we use a single number to summarize the contents of a data set. The four quantities we are concerned with will be the standard deviation, variance, inter quartile range (IQR), and range.
The big question to answer is why do we care? Generally, data can be described with two measures - one of central tendency and one of spread, these two numbers together will give a sense of the distribution of the data.
Lets start with a simple data set for illustrative purposes with only five numbers: \((1, 4, 5, 8, 35)\)

title: Measures of Dispersion
text:
References

El Omda S, Sergent SR. Standard Deviation. [Updated 2023 Aug 14]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK574574/
Wadhwa RR, Azzam D. Variance. [Updated 2023 Jul 17]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK551689/
